title.narrative: Train the Trainers on effective Peacebuilding and Conflict Management to empowering youth and women in conflict-affected communities in Yemen

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
Overall it has been an excellent training and we are very glad with the achieved results and outcomes considering the security satiation in Yemen and the Covid-19 pandemic.
We have provided all the trainings successfully in four phases as previously described in the section outcomes.
In the needs assessment which we conducted at the start of the TMT came clear that besides capacity needs in the field of peacebuilding, SYF was also in dire need to develop a professional administration and finance systems which is vital for every professional organisation. In this regard we managed to also provide these trainings to the organisation which was not mentioned in the proposal. This way we helped the organisation to become more professional and perform to international standards in administration and finance.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
The TMT provided to the Sheba Youth Foundation in 2020/ 2021 was in four phases:
**The first phase **
Training in the field of Training of Trainers (TOT). Organised in Sana’a Yemen.
++Training outputs++
At the first stage we trained a number of participants (6) as instructors to strengthen their facilitation skills so that they can disseminate what they have learned from the TMT to colleagues and stakeholders. The participants enhanced their knowledge and skills in the following areas:
-Training design, delivery and evaluation
-Participatory Training Methods
-Facilitating Group Dynamics
-Communication and Presentation skills
**The second phase**
Training in the field of project proposals writing, digital fundraising, and Monitoring, Evaluation, Accountability and Learning (MEAL). Organised in Sana’a, Yemen. ++Training outputs:++
- Strategic Plan for Sheba Youth Foundation Developed. A new vision, mission, and values, theory of change, strategic objectives, and key performance indicators (KPIs).
- The Strategic Business Units (Programs) identified. Peacebuilding, Protection, Education, and entrepreneurship/Business Development as the strategic programs and areas of work that they will focus on during the strategy life of 2021 – 2025. Core interventions related to each program were developed that are feeding into the strategic objectives and KPIs.
- Two proposals for Protection and education developed. The proposals are ready to be presented to potential donors.
**The third phase**
Training in the administrative and financial field. Organised in Taiz, Yemen ++Training outputs++
Sheba Youth now has a financial system as well as professional financial forms and templates that it uses to work with donors and liquidate various financial payments, such as time-sheet models, cash and checks liquidation models, and also the institution has an integrated management system for human resources, operations, projects and how to manage them.
**The fourth phase**
Training in advocacy and peacebuilding. Organised in Amman, Jordan ++Training outputs++
· Gained knowledge in sustainable peace and conflict resolution based on human rights and social justice approaches.
· Analytical situation study on the challenges of peace and security has been developed based on the new gained methods
· A tool to become advocates for peace institution have been developed for SYF.
· Knowledge and skills on how to develop an advocacy campaign for peacebuilding.
· Furthermore, we have provided to all the participants a kit of educational tools. SYF will use the educational kit to train all staff and interested partners. Hence, SYF will organize promotional projects in the field of peacebuilding based on the knowledge gained from the training and educational kit.
· The team came up with a concept note on how to analyse a conflict in Yemen and developed a draft project proposal on women and peacebuilding.

B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
A lot has been changed at SYF team on the personal, academic and professional level On the personal level, the staff of SYF seemed they appreciate a lot the tailor made training which they received to enhance their knowledge and skills and they felt that this training represented a transformative opportunity for them in their lives. Throughout this training they also got aware of the fact that did not exploit their abilities and energies enough to reach their goals. By building their capacity in the training fields they got new motivation to use their knowledge and skills for peacebuilding in Yemen.
On the professional level, the staff members enhanced their skills and knowledge became in writing project proposals as well as write technical reports. Furthermore, which has been very important for SYF that through the training finance and administration the organisation has been able to develop an internal financial system, policy and financial models, as well as professional administrative models which is crucial for each organisation.
On the academic level, the staff members enhanced their knowledge in understanding peacebuilding concepts, mechanisms, theory and practice. Furthermore, they also learned the theoretical and operational aspects of conflict prevention and peacebuilding. With this new knowledge they will be able to work much more effective to reach their goals in peacebuilding in Yemen.

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: Almost all the employees at SYF are women and they strongly believe in the role of women in working environment and in all aspects of life. Hence, the organization strongly encouraged both men and women to attend the trainings as it also has a gender policy that ensures equal participation of both men and women in any activity. Thus the training enhanced their organisational capacity and encouraged them to continue in the same gender equality approach as they already did.
